page.title: 07Language in Yewdale
page.content: Only the fell-farming families within our area use the{Cumbrian {dialect}to any great extent. The old way of counting sheep can still be heard, with its remarkable similarity to the{Welsh}language, i.e. "yan, tan, tether", cf "een, dai, tre, pedwar, pump", revealing the{Celtic}heritage. Place names give important clues to their origin:{"Ridding"}comes from the Celtic language,{"-thwaite"}- a clearing - comes from old{Norse,}and {"-ton"}has the same meaning, but this comes from{Anglo-Saxon.}The over-riding influence in Cumbria is the language of the Norse settlers, so that their words are still used in everyday life, e.g. "beck", "fell", "rigg", "gill" and "dale" -{Yewdale {Beck, Birk Fell, Penny Rigg,}and {Tilberthwaite Gill,}for example.
